io.elegie.luchess.pgn.impl.tokens

Interface Token

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractToken, CaptureToken, CastleToken, CheckToken, ClosingTagPairToken, ColumnToken, Dot1Token, Dot3Token, EndOfFileToken, EndOfLineCommentToken, FigurineToken, MoveTextStartToken, MultiCharToken, NAGToken, Number1Token, NumberToken, OpeningTagPairToken, PromotionToken, RangeToken, RootToken, RowToken, SetToken, SingleCharToken, SpaceSeparatorToken, StandardCommentToken, TagPairNameToken, TagPairValueToken, TerminationToken, TerminationWithNumber1Token, TerminationWithoutNumber1Token, UnstructuredMoveToken, VariationToken

    public interface Token

    A token represents a PGN entity, such as a move, a player or a chess event. Tokens can be combined together according to the rules of a PGN grammar. They are always case-sensitive.

    Implementations should make sure that all methods remain thread-safe, so that token objects may be re-used in concurrent parsing sessions.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description

    • Method Detail

      • getSuccessors

        java.util.List<Token> getSuccessors()
        Returns:
        All tokens which may follow this one, in the given grammar.

      • addSuccessor

        void addSuccessor(Token successor)
        Parameters:
        successor - Token authorized as successor of the current token, in the given grammar.

      • accepts

        boolean accepts(int data)
        This method is called by the parser, to ask the Token if a given character corresponds to a valid start.
        Parameters:
        data - Character to be tested, provided by the Parser
        Returns:
        true if the Token wants to consume the character

      • interpret

        int interpret(int data,
            java.io.Reader reader,
            ParserVisitor visitor)
              throws java.io.IOException,
                     ParseException
        This is the method in charge of consuming the text stream provided by the token. The Parser always calls the 'accepts' method prior to this one.
        Parameters:
        data - The current character in the stream.
        reader - A reader to the stream.
        visitor - The visitor to notify when the token has consumed all the necessary chars.
        Returns:
        The character the stream ends on, once the token has consumed all relevant chars.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - When the reader cannot be accessed.
        ParseException - When the initial char has been accepted, but that the next incoming chars are not expected.
